questions.question: What is the most common location of aortic aneurysm?

A patient is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm when an ultrasound abdomen wasdone to look for gallstones. He is otherwise healthy. What is the diameter of the aneurysmabove which elective repair is indicated?
questions.explanation: ○Asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm 5.5 cm should undergo operative repair.Indications for operative repair in abdominal aortic aneurysm:••Symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm of any size or one that is expanding rapidlyAsymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm >5.5 cmIndications for operative repair in aortic aneurysm:Clinical scenarioIndication for operative repairSymptomatic aneurysmAsymptomaticabdominal aorAny size5.5cmticaneursym1191Clinical scenarioAsymptomaticascending thoracicaortic diameterWhen the diameter of an ascending aortic aneurysm has increasedAsymptomaticdescendingthoracicaortic diameter orWhen the diameter ofdescendingaorticaneurysm has increasedAsymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter in patients with Marfan's syndromeor bicuspid aortic valveIndication for operative repair> 5.5 cm> 0.5 cm per year> 6 cm> 1 cm per year4-5cm

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding abdominal aortic aneurysm is false?

options.A: Abdominal aneurysms are more suitable for endovascular repair than open repair
options.B: Most abdominal aortic aneurysms rupture into the retroperitoneal space
options.C: Systolic pressure is maintained at <100 mm of Hg in aortic aneurysm rupture
options.D: USG is used to diagnose abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture

questions.explanation: CT scan is used to diagnose an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture and to determine suitabilityfor endovascular repair. If there is a doubt about the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm,USG may help in visualizing aneurysm but it cannot be used to diagnose rupture.80% of abdominal aortic aneurysms rupture into the retroperitoneal space and 20% rupture intothe peritoneal cavity.During the initial resuscitation of a patient with abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture, the systolicpressure is maintained at less than 100mm of Hg (permissive hypotension) to avoid provokingfurther uncontrolled hemorrhage. It is maintained at adequate levels to preserve cerebralperfusion till the patient can be taken up for surgery.

questions.question: Most common site of traumatic aneurysm of aorta?
questions.explanation: Most common site of a traumatic aneurysm is descending thoracic aorta just beyond the site ofinsertion of the ligamentum arteriosum.Traumatic aneurysms may occur after penetrating or nonpenetrating chest trauma.

questions.question: A 41-year-old female patient presented with a tortuous swelling over the left side of the scalpand face as shown in the image given below. On local examination, the swelling was pulsatile.On auscultation, a bruit was heard. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The presence of a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp and face is suggestive of a cirsoidaneurysm.1192Cirsoid aneurysm is a slow-growing, tortuous swelling that develops due to abnormalarteriovenous connections among the subcutaneous blood vessels. They are usually congenital.However, in some cases, they may be traumatic. The superficial temporal artery is mostcommonly involved.Patients present with a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp or face. They are usuallyasymptomatic and present to the clinic due to cosmetic deformity. However, some patients mayhave headache, tinnitus, and/or bleeding. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation.Angiography is the investigation of choice.Treatment includes surgical resection, endovascular occlusion or injection of percutaneoussclerosing agents.

questions.question: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominalaortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG. Which of the following is true aboutthe management of this patient?

options.B: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
options.C: Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
options.D: Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >77mm1185

questions.explanation: Surgery is indicated in an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) only if its diameter ismore than 55 mm in a male patient.If the diameter is less than 55 mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is becauseelective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative managementfor aneurysms of size < 55 mm.Indications for surgery in abdominal aortic aneurysm:•Size >5.5 cm in males.• Size >5 cm in females•Expansion of >1 cm in one year•Painful tender aneurysm• Thrombosed aneurysm; aneurysm with distal emboli1193Management of aortic aneurysm: AAA is surgically managed by dacron graft repair. It can beeither open or EVAR (endovascular aneurysm repair)•Open surgical repair is done by exposing the aorta through a mid-sternal incision and graftreplacement. To expose the aorta the descending colon should be mobilized medially and this isknown as left visceral rotation or Mattox procedure.• EVAR is a minimally invasive procedure in which an aortic stent graft is placed on thenonaneurysmal aortoiliac segment.Complications following an AAA repair are:•Cardiovascular (ischemia and infarction)••• Respiratory (atelectasis or consolidation).Colonic ischemia.• Renal failure.• Aortoduodenal fistula•spinal cord ischemiaThe given image below shows the technique of EVAR:AAorta(cross-section)BBlood flowsthroughstent graftStent graftreleasedfrom catheter(catheter isslowlyAbdominalaortic aneurysmEndovascularstent graftin placepulledback)Catheterinserted intoleg arteryCatheterneeded forother side-PlaqueCommoniliac artery(to leg)

questions.question: Which is the most common site for peripheral aneurysms?
questions.explanation: Femoral and popliteal artery aneurysms account for more than 90% of peripheral aneurysms,with popliteal artery aneurysms being the most common (70%).Two-thirds of popliteal artery aneurysms are bilateral.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presented to the emergency department with complaints of fever andsevere back pain. He is an IV drug abuser. CT scan of the abdomen revealed a saccular,lobulated dilatation of the aorta as shown in the image. What organism is his blood culturemost likely to grow?
questions.explanation: 1194The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of mycotic aneurysm and it is secondary tomicrobial aortitis. The most common organism causing mycotic aneurysm is staphylococcus andis mostly due to IV drug abuse.Symptoms may include hypotension, abdominal pain, pulsatile abdominal mass with concomitantfever. Laboratory findings reveal elevated inflammatory parameters such as CRP, ESR, andincreased white cell count. A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the initial imaging modality of choice.Patients require prolonged antibiotic therapy tailored to the culture and sensitivity findings.Surgical management includes debridement, revascularization, or bypass techniques.The term 'mycotic aneurysm' is a misnomer as the aneurysm commonly occurs secondary tobacterial infection, and is rarely caused by a fungal infection.Any major artery may be infected, however, the aorta is most commonly affected. The organismsinfect the aorta and destroy the wall of the aorta, which may lead to an aneurysm.

questions.question: A patient presents with complaints of swelling behind the knee for the last 3 years. Onevaluation, he is diagnosed to have a popliteal artery aneurysm. Beyond what diameter is1186repair indicated?
questions.explanation: Popliteal artery aneurysm repair is indicated when the diameter exceeds 2–3 cm, owing to the riskof thrombosis, embolism, or rupture and when they are symptomatic.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indication for operative repair of thoracic aortic aneurysm?

options.A: Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter of 3 cm with bicuspid aortic valve
options.B: Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter > 5 cm
options.C: Asymptomatic descending thoracic aortic diameter > 5 cm
options.D: When diameter of an ascending aortic aneurysm has increased more than 0.5 cm per year

questions.explanation: Among the given options, the patient in whom the diameter of ascending aortic aneurysm hasincreased more than 0.5 cm per year, is considered for operative repair.Option A: Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter of 4-5 cm with Marfan's syndrome orbicuspid aortic valve is an indication.Option B: Asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter > 5.5 cm, not 5 cm.Option C: Asymptomatic descending thoracic aortic diameter > 6cm, not 5cm.The indications for operative repair of the thoracic aortic aneurysm are given in the table below.Indication for operative repairClinical scenarioSymptomatic aneurysmAsymptomaticabdominal aorticaneursymAsymptomaticascending thoracicaortic diameterWhen the diameter of an ascending aortic aneurysm hasincreasedAsymptomaticdescendingthoracicaortic diameter orAny size° 5.5cm> 5.5 cm> 0.5 cm per year> 6 cm1195Clinical scenarioWhen the diameter ofdescendingaorticaneurysm has increasedAsymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic diameter in patients withMarfan's syndromeorbicuspid aortic valveIndication for operative repair> 1 cm per year4-5cm

questions.question: An elderly man presented with a new-onset pulsatile swelling over his wrist as shown in theimage. He was recently discharged after a one-month-long ICU admission for urosepsis. Onexamination, systolic bruit was audible and a doppler revealed bidirectional flow of blood.Which of the following is false regarding the given condition?

options.A: Due to focal dilation in a vessel in which only the intimal layer is disrupted
options.B: Treatment includes endovascular stent insertion and thrombin therapy1187
options.D: Yin-yang sign is seen on doppler ultrasound of the swelling

questions.explanation: The patient most likely has a pseudoaneurysm of the radial artery due to repeated arterial bloodgas sampling done in the ICU. Dilatation of vessel due to tear involving only the intima is adissection, not a pseudoaneurysm.In pseudoaneurysm, the intimal and medial layers are disrupted and the dilated segment of theaorta is lined by adventitia only and at times by perivascular clot. Pseudoaneurysm is mostcommonly seen due to repeated arterial puncture for blood sampling or catheterizationprocedures where there is an increased chance of arterial wall injury. It is usually pulsatile andsystolic bruit can be heard on auscultation.Doppler ultrasound reveals bidirectional, 'to-and-fro' flow of blood which is known as the yin-yangsign. Treatment options include endovascular stent insertion, ultrasound-guided thrombininjection, and surgical repair.Note: A true aneurysm involves all three layers of the vessel wall.MARR

questions.question: A 70-year-old man presents with acute pain in the chest which radiates to the interscapularregion of the back. He is a known hypertensive for the past 7 years. His CT is shown below.Which of the following statements regarding the condition is false?0

options.A: Men are affected more than women
options.B: In Stanford type B ascending aorta is affected
options.C: Pleural effusion associated with aortic dissection is usually left sided
options.D: Sensitivity of transthoracic echocardiography in diagnosing proximal ascending aorticdissections is higher

questions.explanation: Normal arteryARPseudoaneurysmOMARROWTunicaadventitiaTunicamediaTunicaintimaTear extendingthrough mediaTunicaadventitiintact1196The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing the double-lumen of the aorta aresuggestive of aortic dissection. Stanford type A is when ascending aorta and arch areaffected while Stanford Type B involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of theleft subclavian artery.Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta. Predisposingfactors include increasing age, hypertension, Marfan syndrome.The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. Aortic dissectionaffects men more than women by a ratio of 2:1. Pleural effusion associated with aortic dissection isusually left-sided.Transthoracic echocardiography has an overall sensitivity of 60-85% for aortic dissection. Fordiagnosing proximal ascending aortic dissections, its sensitivity exceeds 80%. It is less useful fordetecting dissection of the arch and descending thoracic aorta.Classifications of Aortic DissectionType IDeBakey's ClassificationType IIType III111Type AStanford ClassificationOMARROWType B

questions.question: A 57-year-old male patient presented with a sudden tearing type of chest pain. He has hadhypertension for the past 15 years and has not been on regular treatment. The patient washemodynamically stable. A CECT chest was done and is given below. What is the preferredtreatment option for this patient?1188A

options.B: Medical management with blood pressure control
options.D: Further diagnostic workup with transesophageal echocardiography

questions.explanation: The patient seems to be having an aortic dissection and CT chest indicates a Stanford Type Aaortic dissection from the aortic root. He requires urgent surgical management.1197ABThe Stanford classification is used to separate aortic dissections into those that need surgicalrepair, and those that usually require only medical management. The Stanford classificationdivides dissections by the most proximal involvement.Type A is when ascending aorta and arch are affected. It requires urgent surgical managementand may result in:•Coronary artery occlusion•• Aortic incompetence• Rupture into the pericardial sac with resulting cardiac tamponadeType B begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels and dissection commences distal to the leftsubclavian artery affecting only the descending aorta. Medical management with blood pressurecontrol is the preferred choice of treatment.The DeBakey classification divides dissections into:• Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta (= Stanford A)• Type II: involves ascending aorta only (= Stanford A)• Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavianartery (= Stanford B)Further diagnostic workup with TEE(transesophageal echocardiography) or MRA (magneticresonance angiography) is not required as CT is showing ascending aorta dissection clearly.1198Management of aortic dissectionSuspecouteContrast-enhancedCT SOanAortic dissection?Anti-impulse therapy(beta blockers)blood pressure controlHemodynamicallystable?NoTransfer to operating room.intubation, diagnostic TEEAscending aortic dissection(Stanford A or DeBakey I or 11)?Secondarydiagnostic study(MRA, TEE, oraortography)EmergencyoperationAortic dissection?Ascending aorticdissection (Stanford Aor DeBakey 1 or ID?EmergencyoperationNoFurther diagnosticwork-upNoComplicated descendingaortic dissection(malperfusion, rupture)?Emergency endovascular(fenestration, stent) OFopen interventionNoTransfer to intensiveCare for furtherstabilization anddiagnostic work-upNoTransfer to intensive care unitfor blood pressure control,anti-impulse therapyMARROW

questions.question: In which of the following conditions is a double-barrelled aorta seen?
questions.explanation: A double-barrelled aorta is seen in an aortic dissection.An aortic dissection usually initiates with an intimal tear. In some instances, the dissectinghematoma reenters the lumen of the aorta through a second distal intimal tear, creating a newvascular channel and forming a double-barreled aorta with a false channel.Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on location ofproximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system that uses location ofproximal tear alone.DeBakey system:• Type I: involves the ascending aorta and extends through the aortic arch and into the descendingaorta/abdominal aorta• Type II: confined to the ascending aorta• Type IIIa: limited to the descending aorta• Type IIIb: descending aorta and abdominal aorta1199Classifications of Aortic DissectionType IDeBakey's ClassificationType IIType IIIARROType AStanford ClassificationOMARROWType B

questions.question: An AV fistula in the forearm is created in a patient with end-stage renal disease so that he canundergo dialysis. Which of the following responses will you not see when you apply pressureproximal to the AV fistula?
questions.explanation: Pulse pressure returns to normal when pressure is applied to an artery proximal to an AV fistula.In an AV fistula, peripheral resistance is decreased because of which diastolic pressure is lessleading to higher pulse pressure. Compression of the artery proximal to the AV fistula increases.peripheral resistance leading to increased diastolic pressure and the pulse pressure returns tonormal.Compression of the artery proximal to an arteriovenous fistula results in:• Reflex bradycardia• Pulse pressure returns to normal•Decrease in size of swelling• Bruit will decrease or disappearThe reflex bradycardia and increase in blood pressure that immediately follows the suddenocclusion of an arteriovenous (A-V) fistula is known as the Nicoladoni-Branham sign.

questions.question: What is the investigation of choice for evaluation of peripheral AV malformation?
questions.explanation: MRI has become the imaging study of choice for the evaluation and follow-up of peripheralarteriovenous malformations.Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) offers numerous advantages over both CT and radiographsand has become the most important modality to diagnose AVM's. MRI techniques includingtime-of-flight and phase contrast can be used to isolate inflow blood supply to better predict therisk of ischemia following embolization.1200MRI also provides well-defined images defining boundaries between the AVM, surrounding fat,and neurovascular bundles, which is necessary for the planning of surgical or embolicinterventions.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) presents with complaintsof recurrent postprandial abdominal pain associated with vomiting and diarrhea. Abdominalexamination shows no tenderness or rigidity. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Postprandial abdominal pain in the background of CAD is suggestive of chronic mesentericischemia (CMI). The most common cause of chronic mesenteric ischemia is atheroscleroticdisease.The three classic symptoms pathognomonic of CMI are:• Postprandial pain (crampy periumbilical abdominal pain within 30 minutes of meals)•• Food fear (foods that precipitate symptoms are avoided by the patient and unintentional weightloss can result)•Significant weight lossCT angiogram demonstrates both the arterial lesion and the patterns of collateral blood flow.Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) and stenting have gained acceptance as the first lineof therapy for mesenteric ischemia.Nutcracker syndrome refers to compression of the left renal vein, most commonly between theaorta and the superior mesenteric artery, with impaired blood outflow often accompanied bydistention of the distal portion of the vein. Most commonly presents with hematuria, flank pain,and varicoceles.CT image of nutcracker syndrome showing compression of the LRV between the aorta and theSMA:

questions.question: All of the following are true about superior mesenteric artery syndrome except?

options.A: Third part of duodenum is compressed
options.B: Angle between SMA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

questions.explanation: SMA-LRVLeftKidneyE1201Option B is the false statement. In superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome, theaortomesenteric angle is reduced to less than 25 degrees. The normal aortomesenteric angle isapproximately between 38-65 degrees.SMA syndrome, also called Wilkie's syndrome (option D), is characterized by an obstruction of thethird part of the duodenum by the SMA (option A) due to compression against fixedretroperitoneal structures.Symptoms include episodic epigastric pain associated with vomiting. Risk factors include rapidchildhood growth without compensatory weight gain, profound weight loss, abdominal surgery,inflammatory diseases of the abdomen, and immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis andaccentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta.Abdominal CT angiography is the investigation of choice. The CT image below shows narrowedaortomesenteric angle in SMA syndrome:Lifestyle therapy includes frequent small feedings and patients may benefit from lying prone or ontheir left side postprandially.In some cases, weight gain or removal of a body cast improves symptoms. Laparoscopic lysis ofthe ligament of Treitz is beneficial in few cases. The preferred surgical treatment is Strong'sprocedure involving duodenojejunostomy (option C).1202AortaThird portionof duodenumSuperior mesentericarteryWilkie syndromeAortaAnterior viewMACompressedduodenum.Superiormesentericartery-Lateral viewOMARROW1203
